comment: ...I'm such a nerd...
Was watching a Youtube video about difficult to comprehend SCPs.  And one that interested me was SCP-2719, codename "Inside"
A variable abstract-metaphysical pointer.
After reading the entry, I was able to get it after like a minute of thought xD
Basically, whatever this thing is, it can "point" to ideas, or physical places, beings, or objects.
If something "becomes inside", it's the new address.  If something "Went inside." it is now being stored there.
unus annus has become top tier crackhead energy
My favorite part was "O5 - Became inside." "Dr. Zermelo - Went inside." "Punishment - Became inside." "O5-7 - Went inside."
Give you a wild guess what those 4 entries mean, lol

Nose to the grindstone
@AspiringNoodle I'm surprised that it hasn't been reached already
People will probably just stop coming in, unless people start camping outside.
What trend are you seeing?
Honestly, I think it's because some of my coworkers sign off on stuff that they barely did, and nobody in charge bothers to check
So they "complete" the checklist, but they don't actually complete it xD
If anything, it seems like MORE people are coming in than normal
Big rush
Sheesh
My official job title should be "lottery monkey and sanity sponge"
Because people are coming in either for lottery, or they're going stir crazy so they come to us for small things just so they can get out of the house
And considering I am now required to start wearing a mask to work, I am reaching ever increasing levels of "I don't want to work anymore" :ptv-unimpressed:
I'm still waiting for mine, we're a bit low on supply
But it's not so bad for me, as I don't have direct contact with Nursing Home Residents.
Perks of being a Dishwasher, I suppose.
If our store just cut all self serve already, it wouldn't be so bad.  Seriously.  I went to change out a bag of iced coffee on saturday
The damn thing was near full.  This thing sat for 2 weeks almost untouched
vomits
Oh please, they're supposed to sit for 2 weeks
My point is that in a two week period, this thing maybe sold 1 or 2 cups
We keep putting time, energy, and resources into keeping the coffee bar running, but that thing is dead on second shift
I'm pretty sure we end up dumping >90% of what we make

I feel like this place is being mismanaged to a ridiculous degree.  And at this point, the only thing that is keeping me going is the hope that the government will bolster the pay for essential personnel
Because honestly, how the company has handled this whole thing does not inspire confidence
I'm still waiting for it all to crash down...
But the toff's won't really be affected will they?
Lmao, oh trust me, they're getting slammed
They'll just be sitting on their bloody arses lining their fat pockets while the people on the bottom desperately try to scrape enough for a meal the bloody bastards
Some celebrities are poking fun at poor people wanting their jobs back
And are getting rightly slaughtered for it
@AspiringNoodle That is reasurring.
I'll lay my cards on the table here.
I wish I didn't have to work for a living.
But at the same time...
Not having to work is worse for me.
Working, at least, means I'm doing SOMETHING to help society.
Imo, we should still work for a living.  But the fact that we're working harder and longer than in the past, while making less is a huge problem
It is.
For decades, they predicted that advances in technology meant we would work LESS
It seems some of the most essential jobs are the lowest paid
That the hard fought 40 hour, 5-day work week would be a thing of the past
@AspiringNoodle I have the perfect Calvin and Hobbes Strip for that.
But instead, we're going the OTHER direction
Pay is barely going up, but people are starting to work 50, 60, and even over 70 hour work weeks on the regular.
Right now, I'm only working 2 days a week at the gas station, and that place exhausts me
Would you consider a €10.00 an hour minimum wage a decent one, or too low?
Before the pandemic, I was fine working just 3 days a week.  I was working 4, but I don't want to be there full time.  There was a bunch of technical issues that made every day a pita
So 3 days was a happy balance of me not being there enough for the problems to get to me, and making enough to get by and save for future prospects.
But now... I'm debating whether 2 is the equivalent of my old 3, or if I just don't want to be there, period.
Understandable given what you've told us about the day.
Looks like it's about $12.30 an hour, so that's pretty decent
The current federal minimum wage, which hasn't been updated in like a decade, is still $7.25 an hour, or €5.90
WOW.
That's very low,
Some states have started increasing the wage to $15 an hour (€12.20), but it's had very serious economic impacts
Well, the problem isn't that there isn't enough money...
And part of the problem is that capitalism is backing itself into a bit of a corner
It's just in the wrong places.
And people are spending it the wrong way.
Essentially, competition and innovating have made things cheaper, higher quality, and more available
I really want to rant, but to be honest, ranting won't fix the problem...
We do need more innovation...PROPER innovation.
Because the way I see it, we're stagnating badly.
Renewables haven't seen much love because of the FREAKING OIL LOBBIES

So this means that companies have to sell more to make similar amounts of money, but at the same time they can't purposefully rig stuff to break in a predetermined amount of time, or that goes against consumer protection laws
At least there's that.
I hate planned obselescence.
Obsolecence
Good to see laws are catching up on it.
Combine that with shareholders / investors and the highest levels of corporations vacuuming up as much profit as they can, and you got a recipe for disaster
Also, the EU might be taking a sledgehammer to Apple's generational cord controversy, lol
What's the generational cord controversy?
Remember how it seemed like EVERY generation, the newest iPhone needed a new charging cord?
Ah.
Aheh
Please tell me that the EU is saying 'DENIED!'  to Apple's practices
Because if so
The EU is basically looking in the direction of, "F*** your eWaste nightmare bs.  We are looking towards REQUIRING a universal standard."
That's as funny as Samsung making Apple count $1'000'000 in pennies
Niiiice.

"Samsung pay Apple $1 Billion by sending 30 trucks full of 5 cent coins. Samsung sent 30 trucks filled with 5-cent coins to Apple's head quarters in California today. Samsung were forced to pay Apply $1 billion after a law case however they weren't told
that they had to pay in a specific method."
That is the pettiest thing I've ever read and I love it.
My aunt and mum told us about it.
Samsung should have won the case.
They made the damn parts in Apple stuff.
But at least they had the last laugh!
:ptv-laugh:
But yeah, that's something I agree with on the EU.  Apple has their proprietary cable they use for iPhones, while every other Android phone on the market uses mini-usb (USB Type-B)
A standardized USB port would mean much lest e-waste.
This would actually prevent ANY company from pulling a switcheroo every generation
And instead, would cause any changes to be implemented because of an upgrade in the standard.
I like it.
I need to read up more on this stuff.
I can tell you the core of the problem with the US economy.
But tomorrow, I'm just going to be reading scholarly articles on how Site Selection can be used in GIS
Go on.
Investors and shareholders.
I see.
Investors and Shareholders want profists first
And however good the intentions of the boss at the start
Either they are replaced
They have a place, but not in companies that have saturated their respective markets
Or they are corrupted by trying to meet the bottom line
It always seems that companies start off small and decent, then become...nasty when they grow.
For small companies just starting out, they are a boon.  They are an influx of cash that can be used to invest in their product and help secure their business
And as they grow, so do their profits.
But what happens when a company becomes so large that it plateaus and saturates its market?
Well, if you listen to the investors and shareholders, their response is, "Make us more money, we don't give a f*** how you do it."  And the courts have their backs.
I have two words for them, and I don't care if they are illogical.
FUCK. THEM.
Seriously.
This causes companies to start buying up other companies either in the same market or new markets so they can start branching out.
It's far better and more sustainable to have a steady income
Than a short burst of massive profit, and then a loss.
This is one way they can increase their profits to please the public owners of the company
The other way is to screw over the customer.
:ptv-unimpressed::ptv-unimpressed::ptv-unimpressed:
Loot boxes are effectively gambling, and they have saturated so many games it's not even funny.
But they WORK.  Overwatch made $1,000,000,000 in its first year
begins to whistle angrily
Overwatch has made great strides to make loot boxes more consumer friendly
But they ultimately remain the only consistent way to earn anything in game
Do you think they should be banned entirely?
Because they are in my opinion quite terrible things.

That said, Blizzard are pretty generous with giving them out.  3 boxes a week for winning 9 arcade games (should honestly be just 9 games PLAYED), and 1 box per level.  Also 1 free box at the start of any holiday event.
On top of that, their loot boxes give 0 duplicate items of any given rarity until you have effectively drained that pool.
The psychological factors is definitely a heavy influence in saying that at the very least, they need to be labelled AO.
I suppose
But to be fair, the reason they became such a problem is that the less scrupulous companys *cough cough EA cough cough* have abused them and made them as worst as possible.
But the reason I bring up loot boxes is because they are an effective way for companies to take advantage of their customers and extract ever increasing amounts of cash.
EA is the poster boy for bad videogame company
But because the issue has blown up and governments are investigating and / or banning them left and right EA is going to have a HUGE problem in the future.
Their FIFA series relies almost exclusively on loot boxes to bring in money.  It's a ridiculous huge portion of their yearly revenue
Serves them bloodym right the bastards
So if loot boxes end up being becoming AO, or even outright banned, they're going to crash hard.
laughs in sadistic pleasure
So, in 2019, EA made $4.95 billion
That's...obscene
So that's how much money they brought it, not counting costs or profits
oooo, here's a fun tidbit
FIFA's Ultimate Team is the online multiplayer mode that relies on card packs (loot boxes) for players to progress
You open a pack, you get players
That is the only way.  Much pay, very win.
There are going to be microtransactions in Halo Infinite
But 343 is going to try make them as unintrusive as possible
So in 2017, Ultimate Team made up 16% of EA's revenue. 21% in 2018.  And 28% in 2019.
Whereas purchases for the game itself made up 11%, 11%, and 14% of yearly revenue, respectively
That's just obscene.
So combined, FIFA made up 27%, 32%, and 42% of EA's revenue, respectively.
So if EA loses the ability to toss card packs into Ultimate Team, it's gonna take a huge hit out of their profits.
Good.

...Capitalism needs a huge reform
And the only way to do that is to make shareholders and investors realize that with big companies, long-term stability is the most preferable approach

But they probably won't change their tune because human greed is a powerful thing.
So the next best thing would be to remove their teeth so to speak.
'Love of money is the route of all evil'
The courts have to determine that publicly traded companies do NOT have a responsibility to make money for the investors and shareholders.
That as long as they are keeping the company healthy and thriving, the "owners" can pound dirt.
I think I see.
Because that's the issue at the moment.
Shareholders / investors believe that the company has an obligation to make them money and get them an ROI
And if the company is NOT acting in the way they want, they can go to the courts and claim that the company isn't acting in THEIR best interest

And sadly, here's my advice for new companies.  Never go public.
The moment your company is publicly traded is the moment you're screwed.
I hopefully won't run into that problem
Example, Apple.
The thing about the surveying business is that you HAVE to do a good job.
Steve Jobs.  Brilliant businessman with some tech savy, starts the company, gets good workers to help build amazing products
Fast forward a few decades, it removed from his own company because the shareholders / investors weren't happy
Apple starts declining
They bring him back to turn the ship around.  Then he dies.

CEO retires and finance leader takes over.
Giving them control is the worst because the idea the company was founded on isn’t even theirs.
Company A now makes mediocre quality hardware.
They have no concept of what makes the company successful.
And while sales are down, profits are up due to cheaper ingredients in the hardware.
